No you're wrong child. It does that too. It still causes more environmental harm in the way I describe.
Come back later.[/bq]
Actually algae oil is good cause it takes out far more carbon than it puts out.  It takes out double the amount of carbon it puts into the atmosphere.  So when it reaches prime time driving your car would actually be good for the environment.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d753c63687205713c0000#post_537d753c63687205713c0000
Algae oil is amazing.  You could have plants to grow the algae in the city and do all the stuff to turn it into oil in the city.  You wouldn't need to transport it thousands of miles; you could just do it right there.

The problem with it, like I said, is that the process to crack open the cell walls is expensive.  Once they figure out how to do that cheaply the oil industry is going to be a dead parrot in that it will be no more, it will have ceased to be, it will have ceased to be alive.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d76c9636872395a090000#post_537d76c9636872395a090000

topics.body: You won't believe how versatile the "Hemp":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemp plants are. I don't care about the drug purposes for this plant. But man! Look at it's uses.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body: With synthetic biology, we could soon (in a few years, maybe a decade) engineer microbes and algae that produce biofuels. Just put some artificial X and Y nucleotides in them and they won't survive if they escape.
topics.author: 50b70eeb7f123b1a02000097

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d78216368723c0a300000#post_537d78216368723c0a300000
It's also because algae grows very fast and continues to grow year round and the amount of oil you get is something like 50% of the total mass of the plant compared to something like 2% from the total mass of corn. Also algae overs pretty much the entire acre too, instead of corn crops which have quite a large gap between each plant leaving much of the land unused. Algae is a much better use of space.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537d78e7636872395ab30000#post_537d78e7636872395ab30000
Fun fact: the US government banned the growing of hemp but all of a sudden _required_ farmers to grow it on their land because it was used to make textiles for the war. After the war the farmers were forced to rid the crop from their land or face severe punishment. So basically "hemp is horrible, it has use no and no purpose other than the devil's weed. Ok now that we needs it's fibers for war, this plant is wonderful and we must grow lots of it, look at how useful it is." End of war:"hemp is the devil's weed it has no use or purpose." Look up "hemp for victory" Also another fun fact: the US founding documents are printed on hemp paper.
topics.author: 5010fa077f123b1e4f00104e

topics.body: What's probably going to happen in the next five years is that algae oil costs will reach so low that oil can't compete; solar costs will reach so low that fossil fuels can't compete.  Ten years from now the oil industry is going to be fucked.  It'll be the same with other alternative energy sources as well.
